brilliant views. you simply must climb those stairs (or take the lift) to the top of the clock tower for those unbeatable views over Prague.

Prague Old Town, Staromestska Radnice (Astronomical Clock).. Awesome !! At Prague Old Town, Staromestska Radnice (Astronomical Clock). Went in July 2013 , was a little hot that day , But u just can't miss visiting this piece of art.

A must do!. The area is packed with tourist. The Old Town Hall and Astronomical Clock show itself is hokey. However, you go for the feel of excitement. The Stare Mesto Square is buzzing with life. Walk around, try the street food and people watch. It's an amazing feeling.

Great view. The clock was cool, but I felt like I was just checking it off my list of things to see while in Prague. I probably could have used a tour guide to tell me more about it. I highly recommend paying to go up to the top of the tower (we walked, but you can take an elevator if you like). The view was amazing and since we did it on our first day, it was a good way to get oriented with the city.

Very cool. One of the oldest in the world and still working. A must see, its actually hard to miss. It is on large medieval building (old town hall) near the city center. Large crowds gather to see the apostles finish their journey, the golden cockerel at the top crows and quivers its wings, the bell rings and the clock chimes the hour
Must do, only need once though. It's what prague is famous for, for 30 seconds... Go see it but don't think too much about how you have been dying to see it ;)

Not so over-rated... And it's free!. I guess the Clock was recently voted the most overrated attraction in Europe. Well, that's too bad. Perhaps I'm just an architecture nerd, but I liked seeing it. It's right in the Old Town center, which you're going to go to anyways, so why not hang out and watch the "show" at the top of the hour?
Disappointing. The town hall and clock are nice to look at, but the famous hourly routine that people stand around for ages to watch is very disappointing. Queues for the tower are always long.
"A Prague Must". This is an essential for the sight-seeing tourist! The craftsmanship involved is almost mind-boggling.

Impressive!. This is a must see when in Prague and I don't see how anyone would miss it if one enters the old town area. The craftsmanship is truly amazing. It is difficult to get close to it to get a good picture because of the crowds, but one can still admire it from faraway even without knowing the details of how it worked and still works, at least certain parts.

in top 5 to see in Prague. one of the most famous place to see in Prague, every one hour many people meet there to observe the clock show, its worth to climb upstairs the town hall also to visit the balcony there to watch the view of old town square

Much more than what I've expected!. Before going to Prague, people told me that the Astronomical Clock was overvalued it wasn't such a big deal but it really is a big deal! It is one of the best parts of Prague, you can't stop looking at its beauty.

Prague's icon. First thing to do when you are in Prague is go to Old Square to see this nicely built clock. With very unique shape you will find this man-made object was something to be admired about. Nonetheless, the area was too crowd with tourists, and at the time we were there, a tribute to Czech National hockey players who killed in plane crash in Russia was erected and became centre of attraction, with many locals went there to pay for condolences. On the other hand, many wedding couples took their pictures outside the clock tower with their limousine or beautifully made horse-carriage. It was very unforgettable moment. One recommendation: take city map when you arrive in Prague central station, there's Prague city tour coupons in it. Bring these coupons when you visit the clock tower and old square, the guides usually dressed in yellow t-shirt. They are very knowledgeable, informative, friendly...really worth it.

bit disappointing. It's a very nice clock... but on the hour or within the few minutes before its almost impossible to walk past. People wait there for half an hour or more to see it chime... we happened to be there on the hour, was nice to see but wasn't the highlight of our holiday.

a must see.... Every hour until 9pm, the clock does its thing. There are four figures all representing a different emotion / event such as death, greed, wealth etc. The clock is a 24 hour clock and is well worth studying for a while as it shows more the longer you study it. See if you can see the map of the world. Underneath the clock is a second dial. On the outer rim are 365 names, one for each day of the year. These are the list of names which all Czech people have to choose from when naming their child. If they wish to use a different name then they have to apply. The Czech's also name a birthday and a name day...If you want to know more about the clock, then take a free tour with Keith (green t-shirt) fascinating.Also, view the clock from the top of the tower - well worth itThe view the crowds from one of the cafe's whilst sipping a cocktail or beer - again a completely different perspectiveEnjoy!

Prague's most famous clock. Come the top of the hour, it is a swarm of people who are all eagerly awaiting the clock to do its thing. Arrive early if you want a good spot, or you may be pushed too far back to properly see the events. The town hall that the clock is attached to is also a nice example of the gothic architecture that makes Prague such a lovely city. Do check (pardon the pun) the clock out and also don't forget to also look at the town hall, or you will be missing out.
Love the clock!. This is one of the most amazing things to see in Prague - don't miss the clock on the hour, it is a treat to see all the sounds and motions.

Soaking up the surroundings. The Old Town Square’s main attraction is the Astronomical Clock and Old Town Hall. We were part of the free walking tour; the guide provided detailed information on the Clock, which made it a little more interesting. The atmosphere around the clock on the hour is worth partaking; recommend arriving 10-15 minutes prior to the hour. We paid the admission (worth the small cost) and climbed the stairs (there is an elevator available) to the top of the tower in order to enjoy to views of the Old Town Square. Overall I’d say it’s worth a look.

Way too many people, too little (positive)action. The clock and the rest of the town square are really charming and well worth the trip, but given all the hype about what happens on the hour --It's not really worth wasting time to see what happens if youre on a tight schedule.Do bring your camera , it would be nice to take a video especially if you want to show it to your kids, but beware of your belongings. Half of the crowd outside the clock looked like the usual gypsies waiting to prey on wide- eyed, naive tourists.I also took offense when some local schoolchildren shouted out the words:"ni hao! ni hao!" to me and my family ... When we responded that we were not Chinese, they retorted :"well you all look e same to us! " with a tone notches above sarcasm.We've been to many European cities for the past decades, and it is seldom that we encounter remarks such as these. It is also unfortunate that the next day a cab driver scowled at us and mumbled, "Asians ... " (followed by some words in his own language ) . Don't get me wrong though, the attraction itself is charming and so is the rest of the city especially at night but I'm not the first one to think Prague may not be as open or ready to accept ALL tourists just yet.

Wonderful city view!. Don't miss out to go up the tower and see the city centre from above. You can opt for elevator or staircases. Sometimes it's crowded since it's one of Prague historical landmarks so I recommend visiting the tower later in the afternoon or evening.It offers a great photo opportunity as well and since there are always people, you can ask someone to take your picture!

The Clock. Can't miss this. When the Clock Strikes 12 at noon, there will be 2 small doors opening above the clock. The 12 disciples of Jesus will come walking out greeting and blessing you. There will be a lot of people standing in front of the clock so prepare you camera in advance if you want to take a good photo of it. you may want to have a tour into the town hall and city clock. Part of the town hall was burnt down during a fire in the 19th Century. It was never fully rebuilt. The Tour is free though you need to pay for the entrance. Get the Tourist pass from the tourist centre. that way you will be able to save lots of money.

Lots to do - Lots to see!. This Astronomical Clock is not hard to find. Especially if you are arriving on the hour. Just look for the extremely large crowd. Bring plenty of film. There are many other sites in the square!

Underwhelmed by the clock. The large crowd of tourists gathered round the clock would suggest something spectacular. The clock is lovely but the action rather underwhelming. Still worth a visit though.

Not what I expected!. Absolutely loved the astronomical clock and I am glad I ended up on my first day 10 minutes before the hour. I decided to wait for the display and the amount of people there to wait for the display was unbelievable.For me it was very disappointing. So my suggestion is if you are there close to the hour wait for it, but don't wait for ages since it is not worth it.

Nice. The Old Town Hall and Astronomical Clock is one of Prague's major attractions. We soaked in the nice atmosphere of the Old Town Square as we admired the lovely buildings around. We did not attempt to go to the top. This can be time consuming on account of queues
Amazing view of city. A must visit when in Prague - fantastic view of the city, shame we missed the tour of the cellars and building.

Slightly underwhelming. Not sure what I was expecting, but something more than some wooden figures circulating round on the hour. A large crowd gathers, we were advised to watch our bags, and then the apostles do their (very quick) thing. The square itself is worth visiting, very touristy, and personally I prefer just walking the streets and gardens of Prague, and getting a bit away from the crowds.

imagine this old clock still works. very nice historical clock. Watch out for pick pockets. It's worth waiting for the clock to go old on the hour but stops at 8pm so see the clock work on the hour prior to 8pm

Pay to climb the tower. The price of admission (about $5) is well worth it to go to the top of the tower and get a birds eye view of Prague. There is an elevator that will take you to the top with minimal stairs.

Beautiful piece of work but not an amazing display. The tower and clock really are stunning. Probably the only clock in the world like this as the man who made it was blinded after construction (guide tells us). However don't get your hopes up about any big displays when the clock strikes the hour. Very minimal affair lol.
Neat, but overrated. This clock is impressive, but just don't expect something incredible. It's an old clock with some cool features, but I wouldn't say it strikes one with awe.

Beautiful clock, disappointing display. We were in the Old Town Square on a hot, summer's day. The clock drew our attention as did many of the wonderful buildings that surround the Square. We stayed to watch the hourly animation but only saw a skeleton ringing a bell. Quite a let down. Overall though, the Old Town area of Prague is beautiful. We felt safe strolling around the streets with many other tourists.

There are better city view options. You must go visit the Astronomical Clock. It is one of the main attractions of Prague. But after you take a picture of two, there's no reason to stay there. If you want to take a look at the city from the top of the clock's tower, don't wait in line. There is a better and higher option at Petrin Hill (Eiffel Tower tribute).

Prices are not too Astronomical!!. My partner and i had a great meal as the sunset sitting in the Jazz bar watching the world go by with a pork knee and a few beers, the square was alive with knife throwers and musicians adding to the already great atmosphere. I really love this square, you could people watch all day, fantastic..

Be there before the hour chimes. The Astronomical Clock is a definite go to in Prague. One needs to be there at 15 minutes before the hour or you don't get a good place to stand.Shopping ranges from fine cut-glass crystal to extra-cheap t-shirts. There are multiple restaurants near the clock and some offer great views of the clock face. One of the main streets into the central square is Prague's version of Rodeo Drive. The super high end stores line both sides of what is called "Paris Street."

Amazing clock. the Astronomical clock is amazing and a fun site to visit, especially on the hour when it runs through all its figures and chimes the hour. Get there a few minutes early so you get a good spot to stand.

Stunning Views. This Tower is located on the Market Square in the Old Town of Prague and is certainly worth the climb. If you are daunted by this endeavor (though it really isn't as tough as it may seem), there is a lift!The views are quite remarkable and you can see 360 degrees around the tower, so take a camera.
Clock performance very underwhelming. You would do better to watch the astronomical clock performance in Strasbourg. Much more interesting mechanics.

Impressive but crowded. We stood before the astronomical Clock and enjoyed it whenever when of the tricks or statues moved. Great to see and I was wondering how complicated the mechanism inside must be.
Really nice!. A really nice place to know i Prague. Enjoy the sightseeing and the buildings but avoid restaurants and pubs in this area, they are a lot much more expensive then two blocks ahead.
lovely. Something that is a must see in your lifetime and be there on the hour to watch. Most tours leave from here too, there are plenty on offer we used h on hop off which were good.

See the clock at striking of the hour!. The Astronomical clock is one of a kind, in which every hour of the day, a skeleton hammers the 'gong' for the number of the hour and figures of Jesus followed by all the Apostles one by one into a window on the clock. Go up the tower for excellent views of the square.It is a must-see and i just loved it!!The main square in Prague is very very lively.It has 3 churches, an Astronomical clock, 2 museums, art gallery's, Road side restaurants, a fountain etc etc...

Dont wait for the clock to move.... people do that, they wait, get robbed by pickpockets and then they are disappointed because it is not such a great deal. Just pass by and enjoy the architecture. BTW dont have anything at the cafes on the Old town sq. they are terribly overpriced and just around the corner you can her the same for 30 percent of the price.
Hell on Earth. Overcrowded with tourists who have little interest in anything more than a superficial experience and those touting for business off them.

Unexpectedly great view of the city. I was intrigued less than most by the Astronomical Clock, which is the main single attraction in the great Old Town square, and was reluctant to put up the cash to tour inside. But the tour provided excellent insight into the history of the city (as well as into the inner workings of the Astronomical Clock). Best of all, though, and totally unexpected, was the view of Prague from the top of Old Town Hall, especially given its proximity to the awesome (at least from the outside) Tyn Church. We did the last tour of the day, in March, so it was dark by the time we climbed to the top, but the views at night from high up were truly spectacular -- on a par, though from a different location, with the view of the city from the top of the Klementium.

Dont do tour . When in Prague we decided like most tourists to see the old town hall and astronomical clock. The clock performance was a bit disappointing but still everyone should see it at least once when in Prague. It can be very packed so arrive 5 to 10 mins beforehand to get a good spot. Afterwards we went up the tower and saw beautiful views of Prague. You can either take the lift or stairs up and is well worth the time. Afterwards we got the tour in english of the old town hall. This was awful. The building itself was great but our guide (a blonde girl whos name I cant remember) had awful english and was unable to answer one question the group put to her. It was a real let down as the building obviously had a lot of interesting history attached to it.

Busy. You want to get there just before the hour so you can see the animations and see what all the hype is about. It is quite incredible when you think about when it was built but it's over rated and very busy with crowds. Worth a look though.
Underwhelming. Beautiful clock, but very underwhelming. I feel that the attraction is a bit overrated. But I guess it's one of the major attractions that you must do to say 'I've been to Prague'.
i have seen it. Was a little dissapointed about the "apostles" and very surprised to see people waving at them as if they where alive.....
Big tourist draw. BEWARE OF PICK POCKETS! This is a big mob scene to watch a rather humdrum mechanical clock. The one in the Strasburg Cathedral is much more entertaining.
a little disappointing after all the hype. The clock is gorgeous, very ornate. The area was too crowded to enjoy the on the hour event....and it just wasn't as spectacular as the write up.

Fun to watch, fun to climb. The clock show is fast, but interesting- that clock is a marvel! There are also HORDES of tourists that gather out front before the hour to watch it. They are fun to watch too, but make it hard to see the clock if you don't arrive a bit early! Prague overall is a bit touristy, and this scene captures it perfectly, which I actually found a bit off putting.You can go up the clock for a view of Old Town Square. The view is nice, though there are plenty of nice Prague views, and this might not be the best. There's an elevator up, but it's worth it to walk down to see the little clocks and info posted on the walls on the way down.You can also take a tour of Old Town Hall, which was fun and interesting. You get a view of the back of the apostles (in the clock), and learn about the rooms and paintings in the (now unused) town hall. The tour also takes you underground- you learn about the rooms there, which were ground level until they raised the level of the city. It's interesting if you're into that sort of thing.Tickets for the clock are in the tourist booth underneath, or inside if you go up to the entrance (through the Town Hall). Tickets for the town hall tour are also inside, if you go upstairs. Unless you're a student, it's cheaper to buy a combo ticket.

astrological clock. beautiful clock, be sure to catch it at the hour change. Just make sure you don't get in the middle of the crowd since there's pushing and shoving to see the figures in itvisited december 2004
Look very closely. One has to look closely at this clock to see the figures appearing. But if you miss them don't worry there will be plenty of opportunities later.

Much anticipation for 30 seconds. The clock, tower and surrounding buildings on the square are amazing. It seems like Disney visited this place when planning Disneyland. Every block has the narrow streets and ornate building facades all the way to the roofs.The clock itself is a wonder to examine but the chiming on the hour including the presentation of Christ and the Disciples is underwhelming. Crowds gather and all point cameras for 2 windows to automatically open and some figures pass across the open windows. Considering the date this clock was built, it is very impressive, but by modern standards, it is a little over hyped.

Pretty clock, funny people.. This clock is pretty and it's a funky thing to watch. However, peoplewatching while this clock hits the hour is even more amusing. It was borderline comical to me, seeing hoards of people gathering up to film the tiny bells go off ever to subtle and aplauding the clock "performance". It is a pretty impressive piece of art, but the whole thing becomes a little comical. :-)

Ding dong, that's it?. "That's it?", probably the most quoted sentence around this part of town.The astronomical clock certainly is nice to look at, but it's nothing special when it rings every hour.I was more entertained by the tour group some meters away who started applauding.
Great corner of the city. Be sure to be here when the hours strike. The crowds grow as the day progresses. This is such a fun city with so much to see!

An interesting time piece. The old clock is the centerpiece of old town square. The design and architecture are very interesting. We were able to catch the On the hour showing of the little figurines. However, they don't come out very far, or for very long.
Middle of old town. Great area of old town with several museums as well the clock in the old town hall and surrounded by shop and resturants. Remember clock does its thing on the hour.

Really Cool!. I can see how some people would think it's overrated, but it's interesting none the less! Definitely do your research on the clock before you see it, it'll enhance the experience and make it all the more interesting! Get there at about 10 til the hour, it gets really crowded and it's nicer if you're close to the front for pictures. Be aware of pickpockets, out of everywhere this is where they really congregate, waiting for you to look up at the clock so they can do their work, just be mindful!

Blink and you will miss the Astronomical Clock show. The Astronomical clock is definately the highlight of Old Town square. You can sit and stare at it for hours. It is interesting to look at all the designs on the clock as it is very detailed. Everyone crowds around the clock tower as on the hour there is a little "show" so to speak. The doors open on the top and the 12 apostles come through the windows and the little figurinesn on the sides of the clock move. All and all it is about 40 seconds but very enjoyable to watch!

Before going, do some historical research on the clock. Once you know the history of the clock, it is truly an amazing accomplishment at that time. Research the history before you go see the clock. Clock goes every hour. Make sure you get there 15 minutes ahead of time for a good view, it gets very crowded. Magnificent piece of work.Watch for pickpockets in the square area.

Main hub of activity for Prague tourists. The Old Town Hall and the Astronomical Clock are some of the main sights in the square that is the main hub for tourists in the city. The two are very pretty, and the clock is very interesting (but know that it has been rebuilt over the years and is not original). As with other famous clocks in Europe, it "comes to life" on the hour, but the show is not as magnificent as, say, Munich.I would recommend walking up to the top of Old Town Hall to view the square. If you go early in the morning (eg. see the clock at 10am and walk right up) there aren't as many tourists and you can enjoy the views with a smaller crowd.Additionally, nearly all of the free walking tours leave from the square, so this is a good spot to check out before those begin.

So much fun!. This clock animates every hour from 9am to 9pm, so it's easy to catch it. Watch as Death rings a bell and the 12 apostles parade across the windows. The clock itself is a marvel of engineering!

A Must See, but just okay.... If you are in Prague you must go to see the astronomical clock and watch the show on the hour. Just be aware that the whole thing lasts about 45 seconds and is quite underwhelming. If you miss it, don't worry...just watch it on Utube and you'll see it all. It's worth going to see and get some photos, but waiting in a big crowd for the chiming of the hour is really just okay.

Have to watch!!. Great to see, always on time but off an hour because no daylight savings time back when it was made. So many symbols w this clock. If you go on a tour, I suggest a free walking one, they will explain it to you. From what I remember: there is a zodiac calendar, a list of names 365, one for each day of the year, the 12 apostles move and look through the windows, and the skeleton rings the bell to remind us that we at an hour closer to death. There are so many more symbols and meanings, it's beautiful and free. I highly reccomend paying I think it was 100 koruna to go to the top, it is a stunning view, not as busy once the sun starts to go down. No other clock like this in the world.
Coolest thing to watch!. I couldn't stop staring at this marvelous thing! Totally worth a visit and to wait and watch the show!

What a clock!. Didn't know why everyone was standing around in the square for, until I heard the clock start to chime. What an amazing sight and experience. Characters representing the seven deadly sins struck the bell, while the apostles paraded by two windows above the face. I was literally spellbound while watching.

Time Flies. The Old Town Square is super picturesque and the astronomical clock is a beautiful piece of art symbolizing Prague. I recommend that you do not miss this site if you are visiting Prague. You can join a free tour in this area, or grab some lunch at any of the outdoor cafes.
Beautiful place to hang out in the evenings. Most busy and happening place in Prague, many shops, restaurants and places to eat. Beautiful place to hang out!

Cool Clock. Clock chimes and puts on a little show every hour. Beautiful design in the clock faces. Gets very crowded in front of the clock about 10-15 minutes before the hour. Watch your handbags and wallets at this time as it is a prime pickpocket time.

Worth seeing, but it is what it is. Pretty interesting when you think about the ability to build such a thing years ago, but it is a 15 minute gee whiz, then it is time to move on. I watched the hourly event a couple times with my teenage daughters. For some reason it seemed more enjoyable in the evening.
Watch the clock chime. I didn't really know what the big deal was, but then I got to see the clock chime and it was quite cute. We didn't go up the tower,

The oldest astronomical clock still working in the whole planet. Need more?. Go and stand with the crowds waiting for the hour to change! It will worth to see the clock going nuts with the whole action. The people will cheer together. Worth to climb the tower and go to the top. They have an elevator so walk only if you want (what I've did).
:)

Beautiful from the outside and even better from the tower. It probably wouldn't take you more than 5 minutes to look at the clock from the outside and just go on the usual "ooh that's pretty" ("pretty" being an understatement as the clock itself is gorgeous). However, climbing to the tower (there's some minor entrance fee) and getting the view on the city and on the crowds of tourists downstairs is what really makes this attraction special. While climbing to the top there are also these boards with explanations about the clock and how/when it was build. If the amazing panoramic view on the city is not enough for you than you can always look down at the crowds on the square, all staring upwards, and imagine yourself as the pope. Do not eat or exchange money in the surrounding area if you're on some sort of budget as it's very expensive and is basically a rip off.

Have a cup of tea in a middle ages plaza!. What else can you ask for? Just to watch the plaza is a wonder, surrounded by unique buildings and works of art, the Astronomical Clock with the little figurines in a merry go round, the street cafes and restaurants, the little artisans shops with Bohemian glass souvenirs.... Transport yourself to the middle ages and enjoy!

Not as disappointing as is claimed. I personally loved the Astronomical Clock. I went on a Sandeman's tour during which my tour guide explained some of the workings of the clock, as well as what you can tell by looking at it. He also told us that it is often called the most disappointing tourist attraction in the world... and I will admit that if you go thinking you will see a fantastic show with fireworks and the likes, you will be disappointed. However, if you stand on the side of the clock and watch the crowd as the show begins, and then continue to watch them as it ends, and 95% of the crowd are still staring upwards, waiting for the excitement, you will get an extremely satisfying feeling of Schadenfredue...

Really colorful and intriguing. The crowd builds all day through. But the good news is that there are windows of opportunity when magically it thins to almost yourselves only.Be patient and good luck trying to decipher it!

Spanish Steak and Constant Wedding Parties. The clock was everything we hoped it would be. It chimes on the hour and then a trumpeter comes out of the very top balcony and plays a little song. Lovely.Maybe it was because we visited in the spring, but a new couple (newlyweds) would emerge from a door below the clock every fifteen minutes, take a picture under the clock, and move on. It was very odd. I couldn't see where these wedding parties were entering the tower, so it was like a drive-in chapel or something. Whatever priest or whoever was performing the ceremonies was just crankin' 'em out.I would not suggest getting a meal at the restaurant right in front of the clock tower; it was expensive. If you're looking to secure a seat in front of the clock before it chimes at the top of the hour, just buy a coffee or a Pils (traditional Czech beer) instead of a meal to save money.
very interesting. This is perhaps the most valuable from a tourist point of view place in Prague. The clocks are amazing and provide a nice small scene of changing the time.
Must see!. While wandering around, enjoying the sights, we happened to come to the Astronomical Clock just moments before it began to chime and the figures move. Fun!
Wonder of the world. so beautiful to watch, so well thought of, witness to something so exceptionnal really gave me the goose bumps.

Go to the top !. An amazing piece of history in the centre of town. Make sure you are there on the hour when everything starts happening. Also make sure you go to the top of the Bell tower. Best views !

Great Fun - Great People Watching. It's surprisingly fun to stand in the crowd beneath the clock and wait for the top of the hour. There are a number of cafes nearby so if you don't want to face the crush of the crowd, grab a chair and a brew and watch the fun.

Awesome. It's definitely an experience being in the large crowd to see the clock as it hits the hour! After watching the clock, go to the top of the tower, and see the crowds from above!
Another of my favorite places in Prague!!

Surprisingly good. We landed up touring the town hall because we had planned to visit the Jewish Museum but it was a Saturday and thus it was closed (take note - although obvious on further thought, the guide books did not state this clearly). However, the town hall gives a fascinating, brief insight into Prague history and is a quiet gem in the middle of the busy old town square. It is worth a visit before or after enjoying the astronomical clock. (We did not climb the tower so cannot comment on that.)
Interesting attraction in Prague. The astronomical clock is a attraction to be seen considering when it was built. Around you can visit many more local attractions and restaurants.

old town hall is very nice. Visiting the old town hall costs about 100k (4 euro), this is very cheap since there is a 1 hour guided visit included. This place is a must see. The tower can also be visited but this is less interesting although there is a very nice view of the city. The astronomical clock is not worth to look at. There is a huge amount of tourists watching and about everybody is disappointed afterwards.

Incredible. As the Old Town Hall, the Astronomical Clock are "musts" of the city, like Tower Bridge in London or the Tour Eiffel in Paris.- If you are lucky perhaps in middle of the crowd of tourists you will find a guide that can explain you how the clock works,.

Clock is smaller than it looks in guidebooks LOL. but was still extraordinary. The climb to the top of the tower was worth it for the views. We took many, many pictures at the top and we were present when the trumpet player played from the top of the tower.

Tourist viewing. The area was great! The clock was interesting but when it was time to chime, there were too many tourists crowded in a small area. The area is wonderful for shopping, outdoor cafes, etc. I loved it. The clock was unique.

quite a climb. Loved the clock tower. Stairs were long and steep. There is a lift but queues were terrible. Plenty of multilingual signage and explanation. 360 degree views were worth the climb. The final 2 floors are served by a low and narrow spiral staircase which is supposedly controlled by a traffic light system which most people seemed to either miss or ignore! Can't remember what the admission charge was but didn't feel ripped off.
Great views from the clock tower!. This does not take a lot of time and is well worth it. You can see all of Prague in all directions from the clock tower.

High and low. We got a ticket for the tower (great views over the Old Town) and for town hall and underground (cellers that were at ground level until they raised the town to stop flooding). Cost 160CZK (about $8) and 120CZK ($6) for seniors. Excellent value for a tour in English (and if you get there a few minutes before the hour you can see the figures in the clock from the inside - i.e. you can actually see them!) Thoroughly recommended.

Get there 10mins BEFORE the hour!. You should arrive here at least 10mins before the hour otherwise you'll be fighting for a spot. On the hour, two doors open up and a parade of figurines start dancing and twirling about. It's difficult to see if you're not right in front of the clock. And remember to watch your purse or wallet because thieves love this spot!

An Hourly Let Down. We'd heard a lot about the Astronomical Clock. We arrived there and we saw it, as well as the town hall, are very beautiful and worth seeing. Within minutes the group of a dozen had swollen to a group of hundreds all staring excitedly at this clock. This time ticked down and it was finally the stroke of midday... all eyes were on the two blue doors below the golden cockerel, when they opened I stared blankly at the biggest disappointment Prague had to offer! 4 figures just rotate in each window and then it closes. The trumpeter in Krakow's St Mary's Church has nothing to fear! It's free so I shouldn't be so miserable!

Not to be missed. The Astronomical Clock is a true marvel! There are tons of tourists but it is worth the crowds. Our guide book warned that this area can be a haven for pickpockets, so beware! The Old Town Hall has a beautiful facade. Be sure to stop on your way through the square.

Well worth visiting. The tower has a pair of lifts so anybody can get up to the top, where there are fantastic views of the city. There is an outer walkway around the top giving 360 degree views, but for those who do not want to venture out there is an inner sanctum with glass windows all around. Good value for money at 100CZK.

Beautiful and unique!. Prague’s Old Town Hall is architecturally stunning and the history and craftsmanship of the astronomical clock are unbelievable. The actual clock is unlike any other attraction we’ve seen and, although we were not astounded by the display that occurs every hour, on the hour, in front of an impenetrable crowd, it had a certain charm and I feel that it shouldn’t be missed as part of the Prague experience. After we’d watched the display and the crowds had dissipated slightly, we decided to use the lift to go up to the top of the Old Town Hall. The view was stunning and stretched far out over Prague. If you are not afraid of heights (there are safety bars above the wall, although it doesn't look like it from below!), it is a must-see and is still one of the most memorable parts of our visit to Prague. We spent quite a while just taking in the sights and only decided to leave when it started to get busy again as it neared the hour. My advice would be, if you are keen to avoid the crowds and mainly want to see the breath-taking views, avoid visiting on the hour, but if you want to see a little part of Prague tradition, get there in time to see the display start!
Excellent. The second best site in Prague (after Karlo's Bridge) for me. Lot of tourists, be aware of pick pocketing. Must be seen.
Entertaining clock. This is a popular site with tourists who gather to watch the Procession of the Apostles. It is mounted on the Town Hall Tower. The figures move every hour.
Beautiful clock. Beautiful clock and nice display when the clock strikes the hour. Gets busy near the hour so try to get a good view by staying closeby.
Amazing to see. Built in 1410 this is the oldest working astrological clock in the world. It's beautiful to see today and amazing to think it was originally conceived and constructed in the1400's.
unmissable. The clock is fascinating (best view from Mozart cafe across street) Pay the money & go up the tower from breaktaking vies of the Old Town Square and the city. Truely unforgettable
little cute clock's show. i expected to see something really amazing because of big crowd next to clock. It was worth to see, but wasnt miracle actually
Busy spot. This part of old town can be very busy, but the view from the tower is great! If you're in old town you have to see this place. And as mentioned, try to be there on the hour.

A Unique and Must See One of a Kind Landmark. This 13th century tower with it's famous astronomical clock is one of the dominating treasures in Old Town Square. A must trip to the top of the tower reveals spectacular views of the city and if you choose to climb up museum quality background and history of the clock and it's unique mechanism. No one knows for sure how old this marvel is, but a reference from Dante's Divine Comedy suggest the technology existed as early as 1305. There is a modern elevator available which is blended beautifully with the historic clock tower if the 6 or 7 story climb is not your thing. Of course you will want to witness from the ground level the clock as it heralds each hour with wonderful miniature animated sculpture's that magically appear.

On the hour. Before you go, read up on the history of the clock or you're liable to be confused what everything does. Be sure you visit the clock on the hour so you can see motions and be prepared because it all happens pretty quickly.
Such beauty. When you're in Prague you will without a doubt pass by this clock. You should stop for a moment and just look at this beautiful clock. When you do, you'll see that it says it all.
just amazing!. It's gorgeous!! To enjoy it properly, I recommend doing the Sandemans' New Prague free walking tour, because they will tell you about the history and details of the clock.

See it on the hour . Very cool and different, Id recommend watching the clock strike the hour, it's ok plays a little tune. We went the the top as well there's a lift thankfully as we had done far to many steps on our trip, but the views would have been worth walking to the top!
Nice relaxing walk. On a sunny day this is a really nice strol really nice architecture. And the astronomical clock is really impressive.
Unimpressive!. The crowds gather about 10 minutes before the hour ( beware of opportunistic pickpockets) and then the 40 second display happens leaving everyone underwhelmed.
Beautiful. Prague old town was a beautiful place to visit. After walking over the Charles Bridge into the centre & waiting for the Astronomical clock to chime we were in a different world. Magical.

Catch the Tour. The last tour in English leaves at 8.30 pm and ends at 10 pm. Our tour guide was an extremely peppy energetic young lady who gesticulated and gave us the history of Prague with interesting anecdotes. The view of the city on the tower is excellent and they have an effective comfortable lift.

Worthwhile to watch the Chiming Hourly. The astronomical clock is the oldest and most elaborate clocks built in Prague and dates back to Year 1338 when the tower was constructed before the clock was first installed in Year 1410and rebuilt in Year 1490 by Master Hanus. All this infor was provided by our walking tour guide who gave us a running commentary on the history and its working mechanism.On the hour, it will have a routine chiming with all the figures of the 12 apostles taking a peek at the crowd below from its tower (see pics) from 09.00am to 9.00pm daily.As the attraction is situated in the main Old Town Hall Square, you will be awed by the historic buildings around but take care of your personal belongings. Pick pockets are around and you have to be careful not to be targeted.The Prague Information Service is found next to the Astronomical Clock which will provide you all the info you need to see Prague..

Look out for Keith..Green t shirt Free walk tour. We hung around awaiting the clock to strike along with a huge crowd of other tourists. Certainly the mechanism to do what it does is amazing..but best of all we hooked onto a free walking tour with keith in a green T shirt. HE WAS GREAT..FIND HIM AND DO IT
Astronomical Clock - Prague. The astronomical clock is quite impressive with it's many hands. However, I found it a little anti-climatic and underwhelming. I was expecting something much grander.

Old Town Hall. For 100 Chech you can go on a guided tour of the Old Town Hall. You get to go behind the scene of the astronomical clock and see how the mechanism works. Tour in English ran at 11:30 and 4:30. The tour lasts about 45 minutes and goes down to the old chambers of the tower. Felt it was worthwhile.
A must see. If you don't go anywhere else go and see this. Get a guide who will explain the clock. We were mesmerised by it and it's history. We visited this area several time during our stay.

Lots of fun, be watchful for pick pockets and money changers. When watching the clock be mindful of a few screwballs that will bump into you and try to be-friend you trying to exchange money with you, anyone trying to strike up a conversation in "Old Town" are up to no good..otherwise super place to visit

Cheap for great view!. If you want to go to the top of the tower it's only 100 Czech Crown. So this is not that expensive for an exeptional view over the rooftops of Prague and the square. It is really nice. And also the clock is worth an photo for your collection!

Very pretty. Well worth a visit. Gets very busy around the hour mark as people gather to watch the clock chime. Worth a look though as the statues above it move and the windows at the top show the 12 apostles walking past it.
Quirky Clock. Be there on the Hour to see the Characters emerge from the Clock. Especially the bell ringing skeleton

Great Clock to see! Lots of Crowds though!. Really worth seeing this area and the clock but unfortunately most of the time its very crowded with tourists and tour groups! Its worth it to come at the lesser popular hours and have a look at your own convenience!
Great view, see the clock on the hour. Climb to the top for the postcard view of the old town (about $5) and worth being around the clock to see the little show on the hour!

Beautiful!. Even without its age (around 300) it's still a beautiful and amazing clock. It is situated in the middle of old square, so after taking in the clock it's a great place to people watch. Especially since tourist and locals (lots of wedding parties came there to take pictures) are getting and taking pictures taken at the clock. Also between 9-9, every hour, the skeleton on the clock will ring the bell followed by a parade of the 12 Apostles.

Interesting, but not worth a detour. If you are walking through old town square and it's close to the top of the hour, it may be worth milling about for a few minutes. However, I would not write this in as something to plan. Chances are you will be walking by several times, and hopefully one of those times is close enough that you can witness the clock's little show. It is silly, cheesy and definitely underwhelming...still cute though.

Make Time for this Clock!. Locals have got very blasé about having the famous Astronomical Clock in their midst but sightseers flock there on the hour every hour when figures of the 12 apostles appear at two little windows as the clock strikes. Don't worry about getting right at the front of the crowd as you can see the apostles doing their thing as long as you are facing the clock. Our guide for the day, Michael from Sandemans, told us the macabre story of how the maker of this incredible time piece had his eyes and tongue removed so that he wouldn't pass on his clock-making secrets. In turn, he sabotaged his creation by listening to its movement and making it stop for many years. This is just one of the fascinating tales of Prague. Just as fascinating is sitting in the Old Square and people watching - all characters and countries are there. On any given day there could be a pianist playing requests, people making giant bubbles, a cockatoo or two and living statues - together with beggars who seem to have adopted a kind of martyr pose on their knees, their backs bent and their palms upwards - a position they can stay in for hours at a time. Younger visitors will get hussled by guys trying to recruit them for one of Prague's many nightly pub crawls. Eating and drinking close to the Astronomical Clock is not the cheapest choice as it is obviously a readymade tourist trap but it is still worth lingering a while to take it all in. Then meander off to the Jewish Quarter or Charles Bridge.

One of a kind spectacle. The old tower was impressive but you walk to the side and are confronted by this magnificent splendid clock. Unique one of a kind, and if that is not enough on the hour it chimes and moves. Bit of a crowd but good see. Or just sit at a cafe opposite and take it all in, wonderful atmosphere.

Views from the Tower are Magnificent. Old Town Hall and the Clock are a must-see. In fact, if you had just one day in Prague this would need to be a "must-do" site. You need to go to the top of the Tower for the stunning 360 degree views of Prague. There is an elevator that will take you almost to the top. Once at the top you walk around the tower clockwise. There is excellent signage in Czech as well as English. Our 10 year old daughter was enthralled with the views.As for the clock, you need to be there just a few minutes prior to the top of the hour for the "show". You need a guidebook to explain the clock face itself as well as what will happen at the top of the hour. It is a very quick show, but fun to watch.

History comes alive. The main square in Prague is a must see for anyone visiting the Czech Republic. In summer, there is always an entertainer or event in the main square, and hundreds of shops and pubs line the square and several blocks in every direction. The astronomical clock is the center piece, still working after 300 years. Tourists are everywhere and hard to find a quiet spot, but a walk down a small alley can bring a surprise shop or hidden pub. The walk up to the top of the clock tower is worth the view over the square. Most everything is near here -- the Charles bridge, the Jewish quarter, etc. and the public system of trams and metros make getting to and from here a breeze. I live in the southwest US where we have no public transport system, and even I could figure out how to catch trams and metros in just a single day. We drove to our hotel and left the car there for the whole week while using local transport, which is fast, convenient, and cheap. A 24 hour ticket which lets you use all trams, buses, and metros is 110 kc, or about $6. It's worth saying that Prague is the only European city in the area that was not destroyed in WWII, so all the buildings are just as they were built daring back to 1400's. My last comment is that Prague is a great value for your money. We went to Vienna and have been to Amsterdam and Belgium and we would go back to Prague again given any choice of middle European country, as there is lots to do and see, and food and shops are much cheaper compared to countries using the Euro.

Impressive. Both the Old Town and the famous clock are impressive and make Prague one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. Always full of movement, many places for entretainment and continuous shops. A must when in Prague.

Visit on the hour... and it lasts about 2 minutes. Do some reading first, or have a tour to explain some of the features of the clock. Watching it by itself could be underwhelming whereas having an explanation helps understand the detail of what you're seeing.
Nice clock, be there 5 minutes to..... If you want to see the silly crowd making pictures and movies, be there at an exact hour. Very nice clock, but I believe overrated.

Worthwhile touristy to-do. Old town hall and the Astronomical clock are inevitable parts of Prague's tourist landscape. Many a walking tours start from here. In that sense, it is bound to be visited by almost all tourists, specially first timers to Prague. The clock show, similarly, may be 'hyped', 'not really spectacular' and 'too short to be sweet', but it remains a 'must-do'. Be there on the hour to enjoy the rush of tourists, the art and science behind the clockwork and of course the interesting stories associated with it.
Not your normal Cuckoo Clock. We were a little surprised at how short the clocks display lasted. The square and astronomical clock was worth the time spent.
Wonderful clock Great view from the tower. Its a beautiful clock, the hour show is just a curiosity, but what you shouldnt miss is the view from the tower, its amazing!

Interesting odd clock. The clock itself is beautiful, but one needs to remember that it is not a time teller in the normal sense, it shows the time of sun and moon revolving around the earth, and that is what makes it unusual. The regular clocks on the tower are okay and the automaton of the 12 saints is okay, but very a quick movement.

Wonderful view. Would definitely recommend this place to any of Prague visitors (and residents as well) - especially the guided tour. The guide we had was awesome, he told us many interesting things about the history of Prague and Old Town Hall. And the view from the tower is just terrific! The tower is also accesible by elevator.
Beauty.. Take the free walking tour and learn about this place before you ever dare bashing it. The clock is a real thing of beauty that deserves some respect and admiration. I simply loved it!

Underwhelming. After reading lots about this in tour guides and books, it was high on my list. In truth, the astronomical clock display (which happens on the hour) lasted about 10-15 seconds. It was probably impressive when it was created but **do not** go out of your way to see it!! That said, if you're in the area, you might as well.

Short and sweet!. The clock is on the 'Must See' list and it's fascinating because it's so old and still in working order but make sure you get there in time - it's always crowded and it's all over in a very short time!

Still works!. It is the oldest functional astronomical clock, every hour you will see a mechanical function. Great value to the square where is located. Notice the skull that rings a bell (in the hourly change) representing one hour closer to death... symbolic but certain!

Great place for people watching. The clock is pretty cool but even more fun is it to watch people waiting for the clock to do its thing and then see their disappointed faces. The clock is a few hundred years old and was pretty awesome back in the days. Not sure what people expect.

Fun clock and people watching. The story of the clock is an interesting bit of history. We got our info from Rick Steve's but I think information might be also available at the nearby tourist info center (look at clock then look left on the building next to the clock and there it is). We found the first chime entertaining. But hen we found an ideal bar table to watch people and that was the best - watching the gathering, chime and dissemination of people. Watch your pockets here.

It's squishy up the top. Lovely views but try to time your visit so it doesn't coincide with a big group. Oh, and it's ONE WAY around the top, so many people don't bother reading and then push past those of us doing the right thing, most annoying.

Lovely square. Great place to gather and crowds gather to watch the Astronomical clock on the hour. Lovely cafes all around, markets, beer bike goes around the square which looks fun. Lots of horse drawn carriages, buskers. Lovely view of churches. Beautiful at night

Check it off your list, but don't plan on staying long. This is an iconic place that you have to visit in Prague... so go and see it just to check it off your list. The clock was pretty amazing when it was constructed, but for all the anticipation the actual chime is pretty underwhelming by today's standards. Again, it is worth seeing, but it won't take very long and seeing it once will probably be enough. The Old Town Hall has a tower that you can ascend to get a very nice view of the square and the town. That was definitely worth doing for the pictures!
A bit overhyped. Ok it is a bit of fun in a fun area but really not much to see. Personally I found the Glockenspiel in Munich far superior to this.
Clock very disappointing. We liked the climb up the tower and views from there (a bit expensive compared to most Prague sights). The clock is very disappointing as not much happens.

The Interior of the Astronomical Clock: A Must See. Too many tourists are satisfied with just the show of the Astronomical Clock when it runs on the hour. To know more about this Clock, one must spend some money to get a chance to see the inside. In particular, the guided tour will take you back in time layer by layer, century after century. You can see important paintings of Jan Hus (religious leader) at Constance and John Amos Comenius (philosopher). There are also torture equipment, a dungeon, two water tanks, a well which still has water in it, a stone carving dated 1699, etc. All these are history of Prague and shall not be missed if you have time. Beware there are only a very limited number of guided tours everyday. The day I went, there was only 1 English guided tour at 9:30 a.m. for the entire day. If you missed it, you have to wait for another day. Guided tours of other languages on that day included Deutsch at 10 a.m., Cesky at 4:30 p.m., and Francais at 5:00 p.m. Those were all the tours of that day. It is therefore important to plan ahead and determine what you want to see before you go there.

Not as exciting as everyone thinks. The clock; I think a lot of people expected some amazing show when the hour struck, but it's a 15 century invention and I knew it wouldn't be incredibly spectacular, it's worth watching the clock on the hour but don't expect massive things. A lot of people around especially on weekends and around dinner time, that's the only let down.

Worth a visit. Its best to go with a guide or read up beforehand so you know what youre looking at. Also get there 5-10 minutes before the bells cause theres always a big crowd. It doesnt go for very long and since its right in the old town square its worth a look.

Very crowded - Watch Your Wallet. I was uncomfortable visiting the extremely crowded area around the Old Town Hall and Clock this past May. The crowds were huge, and tightly packed. Walking is difficult on Prague's large cobblestones. The Charles Bridge was filled with tourists and beggars. It must be horrible there during the summer months. Get off the main, touristy, areas and visit places where real Czechs live and work. Our hotel was near the Andel subway stop, and we ate at two local places where we were the only tourists. We had a good time at a local beer hall, too. Even enjoyed one of the shopping malls.
Views from the top are worth it.. The clock tower has a great viewing balcony. The balcony provides beautiful views of the rooftops, churches and square below. Definitely recommend!
intersting clock. Every hour this clock performs a little show. It's connected to Prague and though always quite busy someething to see

Beware of the Food Stalls - Expensive. We went to the square to see the astronomical clock and it was nice to see, but we were enticed by the aromas from the food stalls in the square. Whole hams being roasted over open coals smelled heavenly and the prices posted seemed reasonable (89Kc for 100 grams). However, when you place your order, the servers cut off about 500 grams of ham and tell you that they cannot cut it smaller. You end up paying about USD 30.00. Do not get us wrong, the ham is good, but you can get a feast at a local restaurant for a whole lot less.

Nice but not enough space. The view in the top of the tower is very scenic and nearly all the city can be seen. Just pay attention to which side you should walk around the tower, because there is not plenty of space and lots of tourists are extremely impolite with this issue (don't be another one). Despite these tourists, don't miss walking through all sides of the tower because the views are very different and uniquely nice. I am sure that my best pictures of Prague were taken there.

Happy, happy,happy.. I'd seen plenty of photos of the square before our visit but nothing can prepare you for the real experience. The atmosphere hits you full on as soon as you turn the corner into the square, everyone is happy and laid back. And no matter how many times you've seen it, the astronomical clock just pulls you back again and again.

Must see. Yet another wonderful building and the astronomical clock is a must see. If you want a photo of the figures (Christ and the Apostles) appearing on the hour get there a few minutes early as lots of other people do too.

Views from the top are worth it. I was not expecting much from the top of the clock tower and was pleasantly surprised on how nice the views are from all angles of the tower. The price of the ticket is worth it, so if you want to kill 30 mins to an hour its worth a visit

Good for shopping grenat jewels. Close to the Old town hall, you will find the jewels shops from the cooperative of grenat. Don't miss to buy some it is not that expensive from 40 euro ! And a certificate is given.Let say a word about the clock : it is tremendous. In process eveyr hour.

Timing is key!. Such a unique sight - but make sure to be there right before the hour hits so you can hear it chime! The surrounding square is lovely as well, full of great restaurants, street vendors with local food, and (even better) gelato stands!

THE thing to do in Prague. Its a beautiful clock . Its design and teh fact that this was envisaged and built so many years back gives it a unique charm . Every hour people crow around the clock to see the chiming of the clock . It just lasts a few seconds . But hey , you cant go to Prague and not see the clock . The souvenir shops sell replicas of the clocks . Look around , bargain and you may just get a good deal .

amazing. this clock was amazing to see, its age and design alone made it interesting. the square was teeming with people waiting for it to chime. it was only a minute but worth the wait (if it is not raining)
A must for all to see. The view of the city from the tower is breathtaking. There are amazing buildings from every side of the tower. Gorgeous. Lots of stairs to climb but worth every step.

A Breathless View of the City. Walk or ride to the top of this clock tower for a view of the city square and city. I view to remember. The clock is the focal point for the square and lots of very interesting and different food boths sit near its base.
do not miss it. I think the astronomical clock is the number 1 thing I Prague to no miss. At each hour the square gets really crowded around the clock and every one tries to capture the 12 apostoles.

What a View. Going up the astronomical clock tower is a must: the view of the Square and the city is beautiful. We managed to time our visit to the moment when the trumpetist marks the hour and it was great fun.

It's worth waiting for the clock to strike the hour. Crowds gather at each hour to see the Walk of the Apostles, a clockwork hourly show of figures of the Apostles and other moving sculptures—notably a figure of Death (represented by a skeleton) striking the time. Then we went to the top of the Old Town Hall. The view is wonderful. There are little markers with descriptions of what is seen which makes it great when taking pictures. The fee is worth going to the top.
Great view. Great view from the tower. Worth going up and there's an elevator. The clock itself was smaller than I expected, but still worth checking out.

Definitely worth seeing. Although the bridge is OK - this was good. OK, so, waiting for the hourly chimes is a bit of a pain due to the crowds (me included!!!) and it doesnt really do that much on the hour anyway (the apostles go around on the top), but it is a beautiful clock and piece of architecture. Also, as its on almost every picture of Prague, if you don't go, you will always wonder what you missed!
Go straight to the Top. The clock itself is not all that remarkable but the view from the tower is fabulous. You get a 360 degree view of Prague that is great

LOVE LOVE LOVE. Love this square! Its just nice to have a seat, grab a drink or a snack and people watch, or just take in everything that's going on. There's always performers or musicians and several walking tours going on around. It's a good hustle and bustle.
Beautiful landmark. The construction and beauty is amazing. One of the most interesting sights. Take the elevator to the top for a view of the city.

Not what we expected. The excellent workmanship of hundreds of years ago is as amazing today as it was when the clock was erected. We thought that the little Saints would come out of the clock - they just stayed inside and glanced at us down below! We thought that we would be climbing the hundreds of steps up to the tower above the clock - there is, thankfully a lift to take us there. AN enjoybale experience, but not what we were expecting/

Go up. The clock itself is a marvel from street level but going up the tower is awesome. There is a really cool tubular elevator or you can walk up. I walked up And was pleasantly surprised by the displays about the clock and the diffrrent movements throughout its history.

Center of the action!. First a warning - watch your purse and wallet, especially when the clock is changing! There are a lot of pick pockets around here! Now the good part - a great part of the city, you can just people watch, or enjoy the many mimes and street performers. Tacky souvenir shops and restaurants round the square, you are better going off one of the many side streets. But this is the heart of the city and well worth some time, don't just rush through it!

Its gives a picturesque view of the whole Prague. Visit the astronomy tower and be amazed by the view you will see of the entire city. Once in the tower, you can plan what historical monuments and sights to visit.
For WHAT?. The crowds go berserk to be there exactly on the hour. Why? Some miniscule movement within the clock when the hour strikes is worth skipping.

A must-see for any visitor. The oldest astronomical clock still working in the world. Attracts huge crowds all around day, especially when changing hours. There is a tower on the top (you can get up by elevator) which has a nice view of the city and the crowd on the bottom whenever the clock strikes a full hour.

To be seen once. This is a central square where you have to go, because very nice, good atmosphere, always full of people.The clock is nice but we were a little bit disappointed because the ringing of it is not so impressive, however the clock itself is very nice. So a place to be seen but according to us do not spend too much time over here during the day, on night this is a perfect romantic place!!!
just front you. some steps from hotel, much people around... make noice to some of the rooms, clock is very beautiful and nice to see...

An Amazing Clock. This amazing clock with its equally amazing story is defintely worth a visit. Unfortunately, the day we visited the trumpet player was not there - perhaps due to the recent flooding.

The oldest one. This is a very beatiful clock, the best was that in that place at 10:30 bening the walking tour free to the old city, a very nice argentinian young boy called maxi shown the city, it was a 3 hour tour at final you give him a tip. Every hour you will see here the statues is moving, very nice

Hundreds of people cannot be wrong. Every hour of every day hundreds of people stand and watch the performance of the clock, rain or shine. This is a vey popular place of bridal photos as well. We are staying directly Opposite the clock and each time the clock strikes the hour we look again and again - one never tires of it.

It was worth the wait for the Astronomical clock !!!. Had been to prague on a family holiday,it was worth the wait when the apostles come out on the strike of the hour.Kids enjoyed the waffles in a restaurant near the clock.
Overall a good site.
Try to watch the clock. The Astronomical Clock is worth watching when it strikes the hour. The 12 Apostles come out as the clock strikes. Large numbers gather in front of the clock to watch it.

Return for a second time. There is so much to look at and figure out about the clock. You need to have a coffee, reread the ' clock info," and return in an hr. and see it strike the hour again. Arrive about 10 min. early, it is always crowed.

When the saints.... The Old Town Hall is mostly famous because of the hourly parade of apostles that can be seen from the square. Actually, it is much more than that, you can climb to the viewing gallery to enjoy the view or visit other rooms of this old establishment. The clock itself is technological miracle. It was installed in 1572 and shows not only the current time, but relates the movement of the planets with the signs of the zodiac. Of course, the main attraction is when, on the hour, bells ring, rooster crows and apostles dance with thousands of tourists watching this little show, rain or shine.
Nice to see once. The clock isn't great, kinda interesting, but it's pretty quick to check off your to do list. Near by lots of great places to eat nearby and gelato.

Neat. I happened to be around when the clock struck 1600 and I was able to see a cool mechanical routine which included music and some other neat moving parts. I haven't quite seen anything like this clock tower in my previous travels so this was very interesting. They also let tourists in to go to the top for a decent view of the city.

Go to the top. Amazing when you think it is that old they don't actually know how old it is. One of the main tourist attractions but get inside it and go to the top for amazing views of old town square and the rest of Prague

amazing. It was my favourite place in prague The astronimacal clock was just like the books say wait and watch when you go don't want to spoil it for you. the weather was not kind when we visited in may wet ,We enjoyed sitting in the square having a refreshing drink or two watching the entertainment which was very good.after a full day sightseeing which we did on foot best way to not miss a thing ,we looked forward to our time in the square.the buildings around the square are lovely.will go back to enjoy more of this amazing city.

must see. Beware of the crowds when it gets close to the top of the hour, as everyone is jostling for a spot to watch the clock. You can climb the clock tower and I am sure it would be funny to take a picture of all the people watching from below. We decided to have a drink on our first day and watch the clock even though I knew it would be expensive, and it certainly was. Also be aware of the high potential for pickpockets, as everyone is looking up mesmorized by the clock.

I just don't get it.... The clock itself is very nice and very interesting. However, that show on the hour is just not worth my time. First of all, it's too crowded and second of all, watching few characters moving around and see a couple of small windows opening for about a minute, I simply don't get excited about that. Other people seem to though.....

If you like thousands of other tourists.... Overwhelmed with people, a large fraction of whom were forcing all of us to inhale their tobacco fumes. I can't imagine how crowded it must be in the summer.

Great spectacle, but watch your pockets!. Very amusing to watch the skeleton chime the hours, the Apostles appear in the windows above and the cockerel crow. It was relatively quiet when we visited, but it must be a haven for pick pockets when it's really busy as people could be very distracted whist taking photos and looking upwards.

But What Does it all Mean?. Very unusual and a great survival, however it is more in the observation than the understanding. No leaflets seem to say how it works or what it means, but endless amounts of tourist 'tat' to remind you of seeing it.The tower can be climbed - at a price.

Go see it. Show up about ten after the hour and get a table at a cafe across the way so you have a good spot for viewing. I'd recommend going to view the Noon chimes so the show lasts longer. Really interesting, but don't blink too long or you'll miss something.

You gotta see this think chime!. We stood with the crowd and waited for the clock to chime, awed by the intricacy of the movement. Then we grabbed a horse-drawn carriage and took a trip around old town. Really recommend the carriage ride!

One of the key tourist sights in Prague. The clock comes to life each hour on the hour and is very popular with tourists to Prague. Crowds begin to gather ten to fifteen minutes before the hour on the hour and thus it does get very congested with people jostling for a good position to take photos or a video. At other times it is easy to get a good view of the clock structure and the architecture of the old square.

Brief and free. Watching the clock go through its paces on the hour isn't going to be the high point of your visit to Prague but you only need to join the crowd a few minutes prior to the top of the hour and the entire show probably takes no more than a minute. Be sure to read up on the clock before you go so you will know what you're looking and and what you should be watching for. You'll probably be in the square at least twice and the top of the hour, so you might enjoy a second visit to the clock but this time stand under it and look out at the crowd.

worth waiting around for. the clock makes funny music and a procession of life size statues cross before the windows above. there is a lot to do within a block of it , so the wait is very easy..clock is super famous, look it up

must see. This is a wonderful ancient monument, the crowds gather for the half and hourly chiming of the bells, the saints are seen passing through the little windows in the top of the tower and the skeleton rings his bell. It's wonderful

Astronomical Clock. This is one of my "must see" places and I'm so happy that I was able to see the clock and the statues that participate in their hourly functions and movement. Now I know some of the statues actually move to perform a task every hour.
go at quieter times.. the town square fills up with tourists so plan going when its quite. early morning or late afternoon.watch out for beggers and pick pockets!

Great to watch the first time.. It is amazing to watch it when it rings on the hour. The apostles come out and its quite a show. Everyone applauds afterwards and its exciting. A few suggestions, about 15 minutes before the hour, we got a good table at one of the outside restaurants and had a drink, avoiding the crowd that clusters under it. We had an excellent view and it was relaxing. Do remember, while you are looking up, pickpockets are looking at you and an opportunity! Be very careful! Another reason sitting at a cafe makes sense.

Pretty. Went on Easter weekendLovely stall selling bits and bobs, very colorful and beautifully decorated.a lot of cheap food and drink from the stalls Really pretty and a lovely weekend! The clock was lovely to watch but got very busy on the hour Definitely worth a watch
Interesting. Good idea to go up tower, thankfully a good lift. An easy way to get your bearings. The mechanical clock is cute.

Climb the Town Hall!. We where in Prague in Winter, so crowds were never a real problem for any attraction. The Astronomical clock is cool, and you can't miss it if you're in Prague (mainly because it's in Old Town Square and contributes to the square, which I would consider an attraction as a collective). The show little show that occurs on the hour (not sure it occurs on the hour, went a while ago), is again cool but only watch it if you happen to be in the area when it happens, don't wait around for it. I would even suggest going 10-20 minutes after it in peak season, escape some of the crowds).The best part of this attraction is the panoramic view of the city you get from the top of the Town Hall, even on a cloudy day like the day I went up. It is definitely worth the climb and the money and one of the best things I did in Prague.

Better visit in the mornings. This is one of the key sight-seeings in the Prague. So many tourists are watching the Astronomical Clock running every hour! Better visiting in the mornings, a bit less people but still a lot! I would recommend watching these from the platz, not clibing the Staromestska Radnice tower at all. It is too long a que inside which makes you loose about an hour for a just 10-15 min look around when at top. I would spend that time more rationally - there is so much to see around Prague.

Timing is everything. Our tour guide brought us there, with time to spare, so we could find a nice spot to see and hear the clock chime in. The whole area is very crowded and we were warned to be aware of your belongings, again! It is a sight and sound I was lucky to have recorded.

get there early. Well what upset. we had not gotten there as early as we had hoped but we were lucky to get a view of the clock, brilliant we thought till just a couple of minutes to go the 'late' coach trips turned up and unfortunately pushed in front of us and thanks to the tall gentleman!!! who stood in front us we got to see very little of the display...cheers. So my advice is the get there early and get in the front.
Hall is great, Clock will disappoint.. Astronomical clock is not as good as the huge group of tourists waiting for it to chime will make you think.
Don't miss the clock and shopping. Interesting clock which puts on a show every hour on the hour. Lots of shopping and places to eat. A few vendors will bargain but only for a few dollars.

It's interesting to see it, but don't waste time waiting for the "show".. The astronomical clock, built in the 16 or 1700's, is interesting to see because it's still working. But, is it worth waiting in the mob scene every hour to see it's figures move around a bit? Not to me. Here's a tip, eavesdrop on an English-speaking tour group to get the history of the thing and then bail before the hour. I heard the tour guide say the show was "lame", and he was right.
No words to write about it. Youve just got to see it to believe it. Its such a marvelous creation in the technology that prevailed then. No wonder people flock to have a glimpse of it.

Must see at the hour. At the north west corner of the square, you can goggle at the clock when the hour strikes. Worth doing a couple of times, as you'll probably miss some of the action high up first time around. And from here, you should go to eat at the U Prince restaurant
Astronomical Clock--Prague. An amazing and fascinating huge old clock in the Old Town Square. We enjoyed seeing it several times, in its different positions.
wonderful sites great cafes. Lots of great sites and a great place to sit at an outdoor cafe. I still am amazed at the clock! This place is crowded though so beware of pickpockets.
Intricate. Quite the clock. Amazing to watch as it reached the top of the hour. Easy to get to but quite crowded around the clock itself

Astronomical Clock - Old Town Square. A big crowd gathers here about ten minutes before the hourly change in time. One should get as close to the front as possible - as many people who arrive later will merely stand in front of you. The movement of the various figures around the clock - skeleton, Turk, apostles etc is quite a spectacle but lasts less than 5 minutes and the crowd disperses within minutes after the above performance.
incredible. the view from the top was incredible. would recommend walking up so that you can also view the information on the walls. you can see a majority of prague from the top of the tower.

Great clock, but don't blink. It's a great gathering place for people who like to look up. The clock puts on a performance every hour on the hour, but only last a minute, maybe. The figures march around as the clock chimes. It's very old and a great sight off the Old town square.

Amazing Ancient Technology. You must take a tour to learn the history and fate of the clockmaker. Amazing piece of work although the hourly "show" itself is quite simple. Head inside for a view from the tower, or take the tour of the Halls and Underground to complete the story.
Great clock. Liked clock.Disliked crowds around it on the hour.beautiful location - great to visit.Worth a visit

The MUST of Prague. Every time I go to Prague I am enchanted like a child of this Astronomical clock and I like to see all these tourists looking at it when it Bangs the hours and looking at the movements of the statues that appear then reenter in their "niches"
beautiful. wonderfuil buidlings and the clock was amazing, didn't like the crowds that congregated as there are pick pockets but still well worth the visit.
city tour. we were on tour and this was the highlight always seeing it on t.v. but you really appreciate it being up close FANTASTIC

Just one of those things you HAVE to do if you're there!!. Our guide told us that the man who made this clock was blinded once it was complete so that there was never a duplicate made! They wanted to be the only place with one! And she said that the story goes that when that clock maker was dying, his last wish was to go back to the clock and stand behind it where he had once spent so much time. He reached his arm through the mechanics of the inside of the clock and at the exact same moment the clock stopped, so did the clock makers heart........it was 200 years before someone else had the same talent as this clock maker and could find a way to fix it! Every hour on the hour the clock chimes and a series of figures move and such. Its a 40 second show, but just one of those things you have to see while in Prague!

Great Views!. People gather around the clock at the top of each hour to see what the clock does. It doesn't do a whole lot, but it is cute.
